CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 15, 1960, pg. 3 reads: "7,000 Hear Senator Kennedy At Syria Mosque - A crowd of 7,000 persons packed Syria Mosque to overflowing capacity on Monday night to hear Senator John F. Kennedy, Democratic candidate for the Presidency of the United States. After inviting his GOP rival, Vice President Richard M. Nixon to "come to Pittsburgh and tell the unemployed and the part-time steel workers that they never had it so good," Senator Kennedy charged Mr. Nixon with being a "risktaker abroad" but a conservative at home.  He also suggested that Senator Hugh Scott, Pennsylvania Republican, should come back home and look over the jobless picture in his own state, and jibed that the "GOP truth squad couldn't stand a lie-detector test."  The partisan crowd howled in glee and clapped and whistled, vigorously.  (Additional stories and pictures on page 5 and pages 2 and 3, Section 2,1 - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Kennedy-Johnson presidential campaign: Crowded Syria Mosque with two tiers decorated with bunting and poster of John F. Kennedy, for campaign rally
